field_edited_text.value:
iIX. COMPARISON OF THE HARBOR ROUTE
WITH THE NORTHERN ROUTE

Chapter VI of this Report enumerates the factors on which a com-
parison of alternative routes for the East-West Expressway should be
based. This chapter compares the Northern Route with the Harbor
Route with respect to these factors.

Benefits to Traffic

1. Conformity to Desire Lines: Studies made by the Department of
Transit and Traffic demonstrate that both the Northern Route
and the Harbor Route conform closely to desire lines and that
either would develop sufficient traffic to justify its construction.
Anticipated traffic on the Harbor Route would, however, be some-
what greater than on the Northern Route. The reason for this
is not hard to find. The two biggest traffic generators in the
metropolitan area are the central business district and the indus-
trial complex in the southeastern part of the City and in the
adjacent section of the County. The Harbor Route serves both
of these generators better than does the Northern Route. It comes
closer to the center of the central business district and has more
access ramps which serve the central business district. After
leaving the central business district the Harbor Route heads
directly for the heart of the southeast industrial area and while
it turns to the northeast upon reaching the Harbor Tunnel
entrance road there is ready access from this point to more out-
lying industrial sections via Boston Street, Dundalk Avenue, etc.
It seems clear that the Harbor Route conforms more closely to
major traffic desire lines than does the Northern Route.

2. Relief for Present Congestion: Either route would provide sub-
stantial relief to presently congested streets. Because of its closer
proximity, the Northern Route would provide somewhat greater

48

ey
ae N
S
Y



relief to Route 40 (Mulberry, Franklin, and Orleans Streets) than
the Harbor Route, although the Harbor Route would be of some
help. On the other hand the Harbor Route would be of great
benefit to Lombard and Pratt Streets while the Northern Route
would probably relieve these streets only to a small degree. A
reduction of Pratt Street traffic would allow Light and Calvert
Street traffic to cross more easily. The Harbor Route plus the
South-West Expressway when completed would provide a substi-
tute expressway path for a good part of the traffic now making a
left turn from Pratt Street into Light Street.

It is not expected that the Northern Route would provide much
relief for the streets running north from the central business
district (Howard Street to Guilford Avenue, inclusive) and, in
fact, it might be argued that traffic endeavoring to get from the
Northern Route to the central business district would increase
present traffic on these streets. The Harbor Route would not
relieve these streets directly but completion of the inner ring
based upon the Harbor Route would be of great benefit by pro-
viding an expressway route along the western side of the central
business district to match up with the Jones Falls Expressway
along the eastern side. The relief thus provided to the north-
south streets should greatly facilitate renewal efforts in the Mt.
Vernon neighborhood. In addition, the North-East Connection,
which would become feasible with the selection of the Harbor
Route, would ease present congestion on the streets leading from
the downtown area to the northeast.

In summary it can be said that either the Northern Route or the
Harbor Route would provide relief to presently congested streets
but that the Harbor Route scores higher on this count.
